description: This American Life is a weekly public radio show, heard by 2.2 million people on more than 500 stations. Another 2.5 million people download the weekly podcast. It is hosted by Ira Glass, produced in collaboration with Chicago Public Media, delivered to stations by PRX The Public Radio Exchange, and has won all of the major broadcasting awards.

items.content: In 1912 a four-year-old boy named Bobby Dunbar went missing in a swamp in Louisiana. Eight months later, he was found in the hands of a wandering handyman in Mississippi. In 2004, Bobby Dunbar's granddaughter discovered a secret beneath the legend of her grandfather's kidnapping, a secret whose revelation would divide her own family, bring redemption to another, and become the answer to a third family's century-old prayer.
items.contentSnippet: In 1912 a four-year-old boy named Bobby Dunbar went missing in a swamp in Louisiana. Eight months later, he was found in the hands of a wandering handyman in Mississippi. In 2004, Bobby Dunbar's granddaughter discovered a secret beneath the legend of her grandfather's kidnapping, a secret whose revelation would divide her own family, bring redemption to another, and become the answer to a third family's century-old prayer.

itunes.author: This American Life
itunes.subtitle: In 1912, a four-year-old boy went missing in Louisiana. Eight months later, he was found. But two grief-stricken mothers both claimed the same boy as their own.
itunes.summary: In 1912 a four-year-old boy named Bobby Dunbar went missing in a swamp in Louisiana. Eight months later, he was found in the hands of a wandering handyman in Mississippi. In 2004, Bobby Dunbar's granddaughter discovered a secret beneath the legend of her grandfather's kidnapping, a secret whose revelation would divide her own family, bring redemption to another, and become the answer to a third family's century-old prayer.

items.title: 352: The Ghost of Bobby Dunbar

items.content: It's funny the things that go through your head during a disaster.

items.title: 797: What I Was Thinking As We Were Sinking

items.content: Summoning up stuff that’s usually hidden down deep.
items.contentSnippet: Summoning up stuff that’s usually hidden down deep.

itunes.author: This American Life
itunes.subtitle: Summoning up stuff that’s usually hidden down deep.

items.title: 796: What Lies Beneath

items.content: It’s been nine months since Roe v. Wade was overturned. We talk to people who wanted abortions right when the laws were changing in their states. They had to wait for appointments, for money to travel or abortion pills. And during that waiting, a lot of interesting things happened. We see how much life has changed, nine months later.

items.title: 795: Nine Months Later

items.content: People ​so close to each other, ​in ​extremely intimate situations​,​ who are also a million miles apart.

items.title: 794: So Close and Yet So Far

items.content: The ghosts that visit us, the ghosts that never do, and the ghosts that walk among us.

items.title: 793: The Problem with Ghosts

items.content: People staring down that hardest of questions: Is now the time? To leave?
items.contentSnippet: People staring down that hardest of questions: Is now the time? To leave?

itunes.author: This American Life
itunes.subtitle: People staring down that hardest of questions: Is now the time? To leave?
itunes.summary: People staring down that hardest of questions: Is now the time? To leave?

items.title: 792: When to Leave

items.content: When it comes to finding love, there seems to be two schools of thought on the best way to go about it. One says, wait for that lightning-strike magic. The other says, make a calculation and choose the best option available. Who has it right?

items.title: 791: Math or Magic?

items.content: Sometimes you raise your hand. Other times you’re just the only one left.

items.title: 790: You're It

items.content: People being dodged, delayed, and evaded—and what they do to put an end to it.

items.title: 789: The Runaround

items.content: The Supreme Court case that overturned Roe v. Wade began with a lawsuit filed by a Mississippi abortion clinic. On the day Roe was overturned, we were there. Stories from the center of this moment of history, the day it happened.
